G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject-matter jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 and 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Middlesex County under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 and 2, because the cause of action arose in Middlesex County, where the Store is located and where Plaintiff’s injuries occurred.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a possessor of land who invites members of the public onto its premises for business purposes owes invitees a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood and seriousness of injury and the burden of avoiding the risk.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.support_reasoning: The provided text is a brief concurring discussion focused on the treatment of trespassers and the classification of entrants (trespasser/licensee/invitee). It does not state, summarize, or apply the specific duty rule quoted in the proposition about reasonable care to keep premises reasonably safe considering likelihood and seriousness of injury and burden of avoiding the risk. While the *Mounsey* majority opinion elsewhere is known for articulating a modern reasonable-care standard, that rule does not appear in the excerpt provided, so this text itself does not support the proposition as quoted.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors.

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a possessor of land who invites members of the public onto its premises for business purposes owes invitees a duty to exercise reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood and seriousness of injury and the burden of avoiding the risk.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the general duty of care owed by a landowner/possessor of land to lawful visitors and describes it in terms of maintaining the premises in a reasonably safe condition, consistent with the proposition. While the case ultimately holds there is no duty to alter an adjacent state highway, it affirms the background Massachusetts rule that possessors inviting the public owe a duty of reasonable care to keep the premises reasonably safe, informed by risk and burden considerations. Thus it is proper authority for the stated general duty rule.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware. Thorson v. Mandell, 402 Mass. 744, 747 (1988).”

*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.raw_text: *Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.*, 448 Mass. 780, 785–86 (2007)
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.proposition:
Defendant, as owner/operator and person in control of the Store, owed Plaintiff, a business invitee, a duty to:  
   a. Use reasonable care in the operation, maintenance, and inspection of the Store premises;  
   b. Remedy or guard against dangerous conditions it knew or reasonably should have known existed; and  
   c. Warn Plaintiff of hidden or non‑obvious dangers of which Defendant knew or should have known.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.case_name: Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, Inc.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly adopts Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 and reiterates Massachusetts’ general premises-liability rule that a store owner must maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition for invitees, which includes discovering, remedying, and guarding against dangerous conditions and protecting patrons from such dangers. While the case’s main contribution is adopting the mode-of-operation doctrine for notice, it does so within the § 343 framework that includes the duties to use reasonable care, protect invitees from dangers, and, where appropriate, warn of non-obvious risks. Thus, it supports the general duty proposition stated, even though its focus is on the notice element.
*Sheehan v. Roche Bros. Supermarkets, In.relevant_excerpt:
Restatement (Second) of Torts § 343 (1965), states: “A possessor of land is subject to liability for physical harm caused to his invitees by a condition on the land if, but only if, he (a) knows or by the exercise of reasonable care would discover the condition, and should realize that it involves an unreasonable risk of harm to such invitees, and (b) should expect that they will not discover or realize the danger, or will fail to protect themselves against it, and (c) fails to exercise reasonable care to protect them against the danger.”

Historically, Massachusetts has also followed the traditional approach governing premises liability. A store owner has been required to maintain its property “in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances….”

*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.proposition:
Defendant, as owner/operator and person in control of the Store, owed Plaintiff, a business invitee, a duty to:  
   a. Use reasonable care in the operation, maintenance, and inspection of the Store premises;  
   b. Remedy or guard against dangerous conditions it knew or reasonably should have known existed; and  
   c. Warn Plaintiff of hidden or non‑obvious dangers of which Defendant knew or should have known.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely describes the traditional Massachusetts premises‑liability duty owed to invitees and then extends that same “reasonable care” standard to all hazards from snow and ice. It specifies that property owners must use reasonable care to keep premises reasonably safe, including repairing or removing dangerous conditions or warning of non‑obvious dangers of which they know or should know. That matches all three subparts of the proposition for a business invitee on store premises.
*Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “If the plaintiff was an invitee… the property owner owed a duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances….’ This duty required a property owner to make reasonable efforts to repair or remove any dangerous conditions, or at least to warn against any dangers not either known to the invitee or obvious to any ordinarily intelligent person and of which the property owner knew or reasonably should have known.” (457 Mass. at 371–72).

*Hubbard v. Palmer Russell Co.*, 343 Mas.proposition: Retail store owners have a duty to protect customers from foreseeable injuries caused by the manner in which merchandise is displayed or stacked.
*Hubbard v. Palmer Russell Co.*, 343 Mas.support_reasoning: The case involves an apartment building stairwell and addresses a landowner’s duty to an invitee to keep premises reasonably safe or to warn of non-obvious dangers. It does not concern a retail store, merchandise, or injuries caused by the manner in which merchandise is displayed or stacked. Thus it supports the general premises-liability invitee duty, but not the specific retail-merchandise-display duty stated in the proposition.
*Hubbard v. Palmer Russell Co.*, 343 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “If the plaintiff was an invitee the defendant owed her the duty to use reasonable care to keep the premises in a reasonably safe condition for her use or at least to warn of dangers known to the defendant but not obvious to the ordinary person.”

*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 165\.proposition: Retail store owners have a duty to protect customers from foreseeable injuries caused by the manner in which merchandise is displayed or stacked.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 165\.support_reasoning: The case concerns a residential landlord’s tort duty to a tenant’s guest for negligent maintenance of leased premises, specifically a defective porch railing. It does not involve a retail setting, merchandise display, or injuries from the stacking or arrangement of goods, nor does it address duties owed by retail store owners to customers. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition about retail store owners’ duties regarding the manner in which merchandise is displayed or stacked.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162, 165\.relevant_excerpt: “Today, we do away with the ancient law that bars a tenant’s guest from recovering compensation from a landlord for injuries caused by negligent maintenance of areas rented to the tenant… Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm. A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances…”

*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.raw_text: *Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth.*, 431 Mass. 376, 379–80 (2000)
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.proposition: The danger presented by high, unsecured stacks of heavy boxes was either known to Defendant or was so obvious that Defendant should have known of it upon reasonable inspection.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.case_name: Flemings v. Contributory Retirement Appeal Board
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with statutory interpretation of Massachusetts public employee retirement provisions and the definition of “veteran” for buy-back credit; it does not involve premises liability, dangerous conditions, or a defendant’s knowledge (actual or constructive) of unsafe box stacking or similar hazards. Nothing in the decision addresses duties of inspection or obviousness of physical dangers. Therefore, it cannot be used as authority for the proposition about high, unsecured stacks of heavy boxes.
*Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Au.relevant_excerpt: The essential facts are not in dispute. Each of the six plaintiffs teaches in a Massachusetts school and is a member of the teachers’ retirement system. Each served in either the National Guard or the Active Reserve. Each applied to the Teachers’ Retirement Board (board) to purchase creditable service under the provisions of the act based on the fact that the act states that it applies to members of the National Guard or Active Reserve. The board, CRAB, and the judge all denied the plaintiffs’ applications because none of the plaintiffs qualified as “[v]eteran[s]” pursuant to G. L. c. 32, § 1, and G. L. c. 4, § 7, Forty-third.

*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.raw_text: *Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 343 Mass. 263, 264–65 (1961)
*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.proposition: The danger presented by high, unsecured stacks of heavy boxes was either known to Defendant or was so obvious that Defendant should have known of it upon reasonable inspection.
*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.case_name: Deagle v. Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co.
*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.support_reasoning: The opinion involves a slip-and-fall on spilled pine oil, not hazards from high, unsecured stacks of heavy boxes. The court’s analysis concerns whether the store had actual or constructive notice of a liquid spill on the floor and the time/opportunity to discover it, not the obviousness or known danger of stacked boxes. Thus, the case does not address, much less support, the specific proposition about high, unsecured stacks of heavy boxes.
*Deagle v. Great Atl. & Pac. Tea Co.*, 3.relevant_excerpt: “Where, without action for which he is responsible, a dangerous condition arises, the law allows him reasonable opportunity to become informed of the danger and to take measures to remedy it. He is not liable, in such a case, unless he is negligent in failing to inform himself and to take appropriate action… In this state of the case it was incumbent upon the plaintiff to show that the oil had been on the floor for such a length of time that the defendant’s employees, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have been aware of its presence…”

*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u201.proposition: The falling toaster‑oven box and resulting injuries to Plaintiff were a reasonably foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s failure to safely stack and secure heavy merchandise in the customer aisle.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u201.support_reasoning: The case concerns a homeowner’s duty to exercise reasonable care in securing firearms on residential premises when a mentally unstable person has unsupervised access, and the foreseeability of a shooting resulting from improper gun storage. It does not involve retail premises, merchandise stacking, falling objects, or customer-aisle injuries. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the proposition that injuries from a falling toaster‑oven box were a reasonably foreseeable consequence of negligent stacking of heavy merchandise in a store aisle.
*Jupin v. Kask*, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u201.relevant_excerpt: “In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access to that property by a person known by her to have a history of violence and mental instability, has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured. This duty is owed to, inter alia, a law enforcement officer shot by the person granted unsupervised access, because the officer is a foreseeable victim of the alleged improper firearm storage.”

*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: *Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.*, 423 Mass. 637, 639 (1996)
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: The falling toaster‑oven box and resulting injuries to Plaintiff were a reasonably foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s failure to safely stack and secure heavy merchandise in the customer aisle.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The concurrence explicitly agrees that the plaintiff’s injuries were *not* within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence. That is the opposite of the claimed proposition, which asserts that the falling box and injuries were a reasonably foreseeable consequence. Thus, this opinion, at least as reflected in the quoted passage, rejects rather than supports the asserted foreseeability proposition.
*Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff[’]s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

O\u2019Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 4.raw_text: O’Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 401 Mass. 586, 590 (1988)
O\u2019Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 4.proposition: Defendant’s negligence need not be the sole cause of Plaintiff’s injuries; it is sufficient that Defendant’s breach of duty was a substantial contributing cause of the injuries.
O\u2019Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 4.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses causation where multiple asbestos exposures contributed to the plaintiff’s mesothelioma and expressly approves a jury instruction that liability exists if the defendant’s product was a “substantial contributing cause,” and “doesn’t have to be the only cause.” The court further explains that multiple wrongdoers whose concurrent acts cause inseparable harm are jointly and severally liable, rejecting any requirement that the defendant’s negligence be the sole cause. This aligns squarely with the claimed proposition.
O\u2019Connor v. Raymark Indus., Inc., 4.relevant_excerpt: “For you to answer ‘yes’ to Question Number 2, you have to find that the asbestos contained in this defendant’s products was a substantial contributing cause of his illness and death. It doesn’t have to be the only cause, but it has to be a substantial contributing cause .... It means something that makes a difference in the result. There can be and often are more than one cause present to produce an injury, and more than one person legally responsible for an injury or disease….”

*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.proposition: The involvement of another customer who made a normal and foreseeable contact with the shelving while pushing a cart does not relieve Defendant of liability, because Defendant was required to anticipate ordinary customer conduct and to guard against the resulting risks.
*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns governmental immunity and proximate cause arising from a parole decision and subsequent actions by the INS; it does not involve premises liability, store shelving, or the foreseeability of customer interactions with shelving. Nothing in the court’s reasoning addresses whether a defendant must anticipate normal customer conduct in a retail setting or whether another customer’s foreseeable contact with shelving affects liability. The proposition is therefore unrelated to the issues decided in Kent v. Commonwealth and is not supported by this case.
*Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 312, 3.relevant_excerpt: “The Commonwealth is immune from suit under G. L. c. 258, § 10 (j), for all harmful consequences arising from its failure to act to prevent the violent or tortious conduct of a third person… We have also construed the ‘original cause’ language to mean an affirmative act (not a failure to act) by a public employer that creates the ‘condition or situation’ that results in harm inflicted by a third party.”

*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.proposition: The involvement of another customer who made a normal and foreseeable contact with the shelving while pushing a cart does not relieve Defendant of liability, because Defendant was required to anticipate ordinary customer conduct and to guard against the resulting risks.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.support_reasoning: This opinion (a dissent in Mullins v. Pine Manor College) concerns proximate cause and foreseeability in the context of campus security and a sexual assault, not premises liability involving shelving, carts, or ordinary customer conduct in a store. The discussion of foreseeability is about risks from intruders, lawful visitors, and an inadequately secured gate and refectory, not about a defendant’s duty to anticipate normal customer contact with shelving. It therefore does not establish or apply the specific principle asserted in the proposition.
*Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff had the burden of proving ‘that the defendant[] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.’… The foreseeable risk of an inadequately secured gate is that an intruder might enter the premises for mischievous purposes. The jury could not properly have found that there was a foreseeable risk that a student would be hurt as a result of being led out through the gate by one who had entered the premises lawfully.”

*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Ma.proposition: To the extent any dangerous condition was created by Defendant or its employees (through its stocking and display practices), Plaintiff is not required to prove that Defendant had separate “notice” of that specific hazard.
*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion assumes, and explicitly states, that there is no evidence the dangerous condition was created by the defendant or its employees, and therefore analyzes the case solely under a constructive-notice theory. It does not discuss or decide what would be required if the defendant had itself created the hazard; instead, it focuses on whether the substance was present long enough and visible enough that the defendant should have known of and removed it. Thus, it neither states nor implies that notice is unnecessary when the defendant creates the hazard.
*Gallagher v. Stop & Shop, Inc.*, 332 Ma.relevant_excerpt: "There is no evidence that the ice cream was there through the acts of any persons for whose conduct the defendant was responsible. Jennings v. First National Stores, Inc. 295 Mass. 117. Likewise there was no evidence that the defendant or any of its employees knew of the presence of this ice cream. ... The plaintiff’s right to recover therefore depends upon evidence from which the jury could find that the defendant, in the exercise of reasonable care, should have known of and removed this foreign substance."

*Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co.*, 403.proposition: However, to the extent any comparative negligence is alleged, Plaintiff states that any such negligence is less than Defendant’s negligence and that Plaintiff’s recovery should be diminished, if at all, only in accordance with G.L. c. 231, § 85.
*Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co.*, 403.support_reasoning: The proposition states that if comparative negligence is alleged, plaintiff’s negligence must be less than defendant’s and any recovery is to be diminished only in accordance with G.L. c. 231, § 85. Colter squarely discusses Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, explains that a plaintiff’s negligence does not bar recovery unless it exceeds the defendant’s, and confirms that otherwise it merely diminishes damages proportionately under § 85. This directly supports the quoted pleading proposition about how comparative negligence affects recovery.
*Colter v. Barber\u2011Greene Co.*, 403.relevant_excerpt: “Our comparative negligence statute provides that the plaintiff's contributory negligence shall not bar recovery if the plaintiff's negligence was not greater than the total amount of negligence attributable to the parties against whom recovery is sought. The plaintiff's negligence, if less than the amount attributable to the defendant or defendants, only serves to diminish recovery by the proportion of negligence attributable to the plaintiff. G.L. c. 231, § 85 (1986 ed.).”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence under the common law of Massachusetts and is actionable pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 85, which preserves comparative negligence principles but does not bar recovery where Plaintiff’s negligence, if any, was not greater than the negligence of Defendant.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover prejudgment interest on his damages as provided by G.L. c. 231, § 6B and costs as permitted by law.
